results.title: Kidnapped; Robinson Crusoe
results.creator_credit: Leif Gram, Walter J Hucker and Air Programs International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Storytime Collection”.
Features 2 classic children’s stories. In “Kidnapped”, a Scottish orphan, David Balfour is betrayed by his wicked uncle, Ebeneezer, and kidnapped and sold into slavery. His motive is to guarantee Unk’s inheritance over David’s genuine inheritance. It’s up to David to prove that he is the true Master of Shaws and expose his uncle’s evil plot. This tape also includes Daniel Defoe’s classic tale of Robinson Crusoe, marooned on a Pacific Island and the exciting and dangerous adventures he has.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Leif Gram, Walter J Hucker and Air Programs International

results.title: Launceston and the River Tamar by John Glover, 1767-1849
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Australian eye II”.
Examines John Glover’s (1767-1849) sympathetic rendition of the countryside of Tasmania. ‘Launceston and the River Tamar’ (1832) was the earliest landscape breaking from the European manner.

results.title: The Conciliation by Benjamin Duterrau, 1840
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton, Tasmanian Film Corporation and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian eye II”.
This film looks at the works of Benjamin Duterrau, and in particular his painting “The Conciliation”. This was of importance as, based on the meeting of George Augustus Robinson in 1830 with a group of Tasmanian aborigines, it was the first painting of a historical scene created in Australia.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Muir, Malcolm Otton, Tasmanian Film Corporation and Film Australia
results.description:

results.title: 'The Lacquer room' by Grace Cossington Smith
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “The Australian eye II”.
Painted in mid-career, “The Lacquer room” shows Grace Cossington Smith’s mature, Cezanne-influenced style and demonstrates her instinctive ability to bring forms up to a frontal plane in Post-Impressionist rejection of traditional perspective.

results.title: 'Study for 'Dog gymkahna'' by Frank Hinder, 1938
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “The Australian eye II”.
A study of the oil painting by Frank Hinder, “Study for dog gymkhana”. One of a handful of paintings which carried Australian art beyond Post-Impressionism into Cubism and its off-shoots. Commentary by Cecily Poulson.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia

results.title: Symbolism and luxury: the new century 1897-1911
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian eye”.
The Spirit of the Plains (10min): Painted in 1897, this is one of Sydney Long’s finest pieces of work. Endormies: A painting by Rupert Bunny. The Mother (9min): Examines the range and quality of artist George Lambert’s best work. The Ferry (8min): This painting is the sunniest and most lyrical of E. Phillips Fox’s paintings.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia

results.title: Sydney: The School of the forties 1941-1981
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian eye”.
Man Feeding His Dogs (9min): A look at artist Russell Drysdale and his work. Madame Sosostris (10min): A joint product by artist James Gleeson and sculptor Robert Klippel is examined. Portrait of Dame Mary Gilmore (9min): An insight into one of Australia’s most controversial paintings. Sydney, 1942 (10min): A look at the work of Sali Herman.
